newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus postal workers strike over privatisation.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus postal workers strike over privatisation.

text.p: Postal workers in Cyprus declared a 24 hour strike on Monday to protest government plans to commission post office work to the private sector, a civil servant union leader said.
"It may not be apparent now but if this plan goes ahead people may be left without a job," said postal union leader Makis Pelekanos.
"It is obvious that when they talk about offices being created to handle mail in urban areas that they are talking about privatisation," he told Reuters.
The government denies attempts to privatise the department, saying the move will be cost effective and increase the output of small postal agencies it already has agreements with to distribute mail.
"Basically this decision is for them to take on more responsibilities, like handling packages, that sort of thing," one postal official told Reuters.

Last week postal workers imposed an overtime ban. "Work was not really affected because of the work shifts. Today's strike has caused some problems but we will be in a position to evaluate the situation from tomorrow," the official said.
The authorities hope the new arrangement will come into effect in early 1997.

Earlier this year the Cyprus Development Bank (CDB), a government think-tank, proposed creating a government-controlled company to replace the postal services department, currently a department within the ministry of communicationws and works.

Postal services are currently up against stiff competitition by cheaper and more efficient private outlets which have appeared in recent years. Private courier services control 30 percent of the market.
